top_comment.text:
I just (fairly) recently quit smoking after 17 years or so, so I understand 
why it's nice not being annoyed by other peoples' smoke all the time.. BUT!
I am pretty damn liberal and I simply cannot see how it's any business of 
the government what people do on private property.

A restaurant is not a public area like a library is, where everyone has a 
right to be. A restaurant is privately owned, so if the owner wants to make 
a non-smoking restaurant, no one has ever prevented him from doing that.
The owner can kick you out if he doesn't like you, if he finds you ugly, if 
he has a dress code or whatever.. You do not have a right to be there. It's 
a privilege that the owner can take away whenever he feels like it. It is 
private property that he allows you to use. He should be the one deciding 
smoking rules on his own property.
If people don't like it, they can go elsewhere. Just like the people who 
find his dress code idiotic.

People need to get rid of the entitled attitude. Entering a bar, a 
restaurant, a club, a bookstore etc. etc. is not a right. It is a 
privilege. If you don't like it, gtfo. 
Smoking rules on private property is none of the government's business. 
Period.﻿
top_comment.author: Gnawer Shreth

+Honey Pot I KNOW!!! I have SEVERE asthma!!! One time I was on the bus and

suffocating to the point where I could not get the window open and the 
people at the front with all their kids and all that were coughing and 
crying and complaining to the driver to kick the guy off!!! I had asked the 
guy at the other end literally begged him to PLEASE OPEN YOUR F-ING WINDOW 
and all he does is start cursing me out (he was African American) and 
telling me to get my fat white ass off the bus and other horrid things!!! 
There was ONE woman up front sitting right next to the guy and she heard me 
and was PLEADING with the driver to pull over and telling him repeatedly 
someone is VERY sick!!! Driver did NOT listen and I had grabbed the cord 
and got to the back door and banged on it as I could no longer speak and 
hope he listened to her as I was about to collapse!!! He did and I got out! 
That ALL happened in 1-2 minutes of the bus pulling out from the Subway 
(train) station and going to its very next stop! Bus drivers here are 
taught to DO NOTHING not even pull over unless the issues IMMEDIATELY 
impact their ability(ies) to drive! Somehow he was NOT effected by it and 
everyone elderly and young in the row closest to him barely a foot away 
were! They said ONLY way they could do something was if I got the guys bus 
number and who the fuck would be looking for that in such a situation!?!

chum etz, soo schlimm isches aso au ned :)
but seriously I've never encountered as many people who smoke like in

There certainly are some stupid teen smokers who do disturb non smokers

like smoking indoors too (since the Zurich Mainstation Hall is neither 
indoor nor outdoor, it's something in between.) What I found especially 
interesting is, I had no problem smoking in the clubs in Korea because the 
air conditioner/circulation whatever was that good, you could barely smell 
the smoke and you could breathe perfectly. Another good idea from Korea is, 
when you go to smoker sections in public places like restaurants, cafes, 
clubs etc. they always put a tiny wet piece of paper in the ashtray so the 
cigarette will not burn any further so it won't burn any other cigs in 
there (filter or some leftover tobacco) and won't cause that ugly smell. I 
think this should be like that everywhere. Or making smoker sections 
(fumoirs) so it won't disturb other people.

top_comment.text:
Smoking isnt that bad or as bad as we are led to believe. In fact only half 
of people who smoke get any type of disease from it (10% or less get 
cancer) and half of those dont die from that disease.  Half of those who DO 
die from smoking die OVER the age of 75, so its meaningless because thats 
about the time people die anyway, average life expectancy is around 78-80.  

Its also important to note that about half of the population gets the same 
diseases at some point in their lives, smokers or not.  So its unclear 
exactly what caused it, but since there has been shown a correlation 
between smoking and these diseases they just go ahead and chalk it up to 
the smoking, when it could have been something else because these are 
common diseases like heart disease and other repository diseases, strokes, 
etc.  

So even if we assume that all smokers got these very common diseases from 
smoking alone, then only 12.5% of smokers die from smoking under the age of 
75, meaning only 12.5% of smokers die early from smoking.  

Thats literally the worst thing you can say, as its very possible its less 
than that because many of these same people would have gotten these same 
diseases anyway.  I personally believe its more along the lines of 8% of 
so.﻿
top_comment.author: old3nglishisboss

comments.text:

cancer patients are smokers.

of y chromosome, making men little bitches.

my father's smoking even though he kept trying not to smoke around me. so 
can you just tell me what is this positive thing you get from smoking VS

comments.author: Fatimaezzahra EJJEBLI

comments.text:
+old3nglishisboss just an FYI: all my grandparents never made it to the age 
of 70 because of tobacco smoke...all four of them (one of them was lung 
cancer). My great aunt ended up with emphysema because of my grandmother's 
second hand smoke and her quality of life is now diminished. She NEVER 
smoked. YOur statistics are a bit inaccurate. (I recommend giving your 
source when you give a statistic like that.) Smoking is more dangerous 
because it affects other's people health around you while drinking only 
affects the person drinking. This is a small snip-it of statistics from the 
CDC (Centers of Disease Control and Prevention; government site) Cigarette 
smoking causes about one of every five deaths in the United States each 
year. Cigarette smoking is estimated to cause the following:
More than 480,000 deaths annually (including deaths from secondhand smoke)
278,544 deaths annually among men (including deaths from secondhand smoke)
201,773 deaths annually among women (including deaths from secondhand 
smoke) source: 
http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/health_effects/tobacco_related_mortality/
 
 I recommend to read the facts. These are needless deaths caused by a plant 
that can be avoided....480,000 who died...didn't have to.  Smoking is 
dangerous not only for you but the people around you. Sure, you may have 
good genes. But what about the people around you? Do you 100% know that 
they have good genes? BTW, thank you for trying your best to not smoke in 
front of everyone. You are a gentleman :)
comments.author: KoreanEireTeacher

comments.text:
This is just conjecture but I believe its better to smoke light (half a 
pack a day or less) and exercise and eat right, than it is to eat like shit 
and get fat (most people) not exercise (most people) and not smoke (most 
people again).

I never smoke in public places, or in front of stores.  If im working ill 
go far away from the entrance or around back to smoke, but never in front 
of people.  Otherwise I smoke on my back porch at home.  Ive been a smoker 
for 8 years and all my tests are great, no issues.  I dont get wasted on 
the weekends like everyone else and I workout.  I eat red meat or some kind 
of meat every day and I almost never eat vegetables or fruits.  Im healthy 
as fuck and in good shape.  

My grandfather smokes and he is like 80 just fine, my uncle smokes and he 
is just fine, my father smokes and he is just fine.  I guess its just my 
genetics but I have no history of heart problems, stroke, or respiratory 
issues in my family at all.  For me im very certain I will be just fine. 

Smoking isnt as bad as drinking because drinking destroys testosterone, 
protein synthesis, and nutrition.  Drinking too much causes muscle atrophy 
and literally shrinks your brain-decreases volume-look it up.  People who 
binge drink (get drunk) on the weekends suffer from this shit far worse 
than people who drink 3-5 drinks per day believe it or not.
comments.author: old3nglishisboss

comments.author: Byamba Zen

comments.author: Jared Aru

top_comment.text:
I've never understood banning smoking in bars. Like, sorry for slowly, 
fractionally poisoning you while you guzzle another, far more efficient 
poison. My bad?

I'm a (rather unabashed) smoker. I swear, I must have born to be one, 
because since I was a little girl, I remember thinking that cigarettes 
smelled great. I quit for two years before resuming the habit. During that 
time period, my nose became far more sensitive, and the smell of cigarette 
smoke was truly foul. Having been on both sides now (twice), my opinion on 
this has always remained the same: It's private property, so let the 
business owners decide. Then I can decide whether or not I frequent them.

That said, having been a smoker, even when I quit for two years, I'd still 
let people smoke in my car, my home etc. I never wanted to be that person 
that criticized or passed judgment, because the stigma around smoking is 
exhausting, misguidedly encouraged and hypocritical as hell.

I've been told off for smoking by fat people, by alcoholics, by people who 
have bad hygiene, etc. From a smoker's perspective, there's an underlying 
irony that non-smokers typically cannot see: If you're overweight, why are 
you lecturing me on health issues? If you're an alcoholic, should you 
really be one to criticize "poisoning" myself and/or those surrounding me? 
If you have bad hygiene, can you really complain about how I smell? The 
"overweight and lecturing" one particularly bothers me, mostly due to its 
saturation and apparent separation from the issue of smoking. If you tell 
me I smell bad, I'm going to tell you that you look bad and assume that we 
were both pointing out the obvious. Maybe next time they'll think before 
they speak to a stranger.

Besides, if it's two in the morning and I'm at IHOP, I'm assuming that 
everyone there (including staff) is a.) unconcerned about their 
health/diet, b.) drunk, and c.) likely smells pretty poorly. Let me smoke 
my god damned cigarette, please; we've all given up on ourselves around 
here.﻿
top_comment.author: superspoon

comments.text: +山と THANK YOU. seriously, what you said, has needed to be said.
comments.author: Candace C

comments.text:
I think it mostly has to do with how smoking does affect people around you 
who did not choose to be affected. Honestly I'm very against smoking, I 
don't do it and I don't socialize with those who do. However, a bar is one 
of the few places I don't feel like it should be banned in. No one goes to 
a bar with a goal of being healthy, to me a bar and smoking kind of go hand 
in hand-which is why I don't go to bars. It's not up to me but I think, as 
in all things, moderation and compromising should be key. Although I tend 
to judge people who smoke (not outwardly because its their choice and 
really none of my business) I think they've been "kicked" out of enough 
places. Smoking in areas like the college I attend and the hospital or a 
clinic where there are signs all over the place pisses me off. But if I 
were to go to a bar and someone next to me was smoking, I'd move, or leave.

The only time I am ever vocal about my disapproval of smoking is when 
someone smokes around my little sister, who's extremely asthmatic, or when 
someone smokes around a child-if its a baby I turn hulk green.
comments.author: Samantha Lindemann

comments.text:

comments.author: Pelle McKruth

comments.text:
I'm not arguing harm; I'm pointing out hypocrisy. Being lectured about 
health issues by obvious hypocrites is a nuisance. I'm not sure why you 
thought I was somehow trying to imply that cigarettes are healthy because 
obesity exists.

And really, who's reaching here: The Industrial Revolution? For realsies? 
The health issues related to secondhand smoke are obviously still heavily 
contested and have not been conclusively evidenced. Slight difference there 
between "potential mild risk similar to the risk one encounters in everyday 
life" versus factory fires and inhumane business practices resulting in the 
deaths of thousands of workers.
comments.author: superspoon

comments.text:
This is a bullshit argument. Alcohol and obesity's harmfulness does not 
negate a cigarette's harmfulness. "How dare the government make rules about 
airplane safety! Cars crash all the time!" Alcoholics should quit drinking, 
obese people should get healthier, and smokers should stop smoking. Those 
things are not mutually exclusive. 

And let the shop owners decide? Yes.. money vs customer's health.. That 
worked out so well during the industrial revolution.

comments.text:

comments.author: superspoon

comments.text:
No but seriously name something that "doesn't" kill you. Everybody that

comments.author: The Manga Freak

comments.text:
The difference is that person drinking beer is not also pouring their 
poison of choice down your gullet without your consent. If your liver was

comments.author: Tori Toki

comments.text:
That stopped being very kind after the first sentence. :P

The whole point of contention here is whether or not it should be illegal. 
We both hold a vested interest in this, a personal stake. We're going to 
hold strong opinions that uphold our own personal comfort levels. To me, 
you, as an individual asthma sufferer (sorry to hear that, earnestly), bear 
the greater burden to ensure your own safety -- presuming you have put 
yourself in an environment in which it is *legal* to smoke around you. To 
you, you likely hear that as, "I don't give a shit about your asthma," 
which isn't the case at all.

This is why I was mentioning segregation and/or ventilation systems in my 
previous post. It addresses both of our concerns. I don't want to give you 
an asthma attack, and I would never knowingly do so. I don't believe most 
other smokers would want to, either, unless you peed on their shoe or 
something. Knowing tobacco's true lethality, you know why they don't just 
outlaw cigarettes altogether instead of these silly, questionably 
Constitutional bans on private property? Your taxes would raise 
significantly: https://www.rjrt.com/taxpays.aspx

Alexander already addressed the 'poisoning' issue. Here's a Forbes article 
on a study done recently: 
http://www.forbes.com/sites/danielfisher/2013/12/12/study-finds-no-link-between-secondhand-smoke-and-cancer/

Would secondhand smoke aggravate your asthma or your friend's? Very likely. 
So I wouldn't smoke around y'all; I'd go to my smokers' area, and you could 
go to your non-smokers' area. If we were in a ventilated room and I came by 
you, smoking a cigarette, and you politely informed me of your condition, I 
would step away. I mean, we're smokers, not sociopaths.
comments.author: superspoon

comments.text:
As someone with Asthma, and sometimes goes to restaurants with bars where 
people smoke and I get triggered, I kindly disagree with you. I'm not going 
to stop going to my favorite places to eat, because someone whats to break 
the law and poison EVERYONE. A friend of mine also has asthma, but her's 
sends her to the hospital at least three times a year, it's unfair to her, 
or anyone in her position, who just wants to go get one beer after work on 
occasion to then get sent to hospital and pay huge hospital fees, because 
you want to smoke somewhere you illegally can't, because "my poison affects 
everyone, but because they have a poison that only affects THEM, I should 
be allowed to do mine wherever I please".
comments.author: YaoiLovingDemon

comments.text:
I <3 those ventilation systems, but unfortunately, they're prohibitively 
expensive, which is why it's so rare to find them outside of casinos.
comments.author: superspoon

comments.text:
We're not disagreeing, I don't think. Even if I don't believe that 
secondhand causes significant damage, much earlier on I pointed out the 
lengths I go to to ensure that nobody who does not want to breathe it is 
forced to do so due to my presence. Agreed on ventilation, though I do find 
it silly when in a bar while ultimately imbibing much more dangerous 
toxins, but whatever; if people want to have a smoking area and a 
non-smoking area, I'm happy to oblige. I just don't like how extreme it has 
gotten; there is no option anymore, just non-smoking and judgment. I do 
find hypocrisy in the choice to get fat or excessively drink alcohol while 
lamenting the dangers of second-hand smoke, but people are entitled to 
their silliness; my main issue is that that silliness has now become laws 
on the books instead of a simple segregation that, I think, would make both 
sides happy.
comments.author: superspoon

top_comment.text:
As someone whose mother died at the young age of 40 because of smoking. I 
can say to all of the people pro smoking commenting on here; you've gotten 
lucky keep playing this retarded game of Russian roulette on your lives. 
When you end up with cancer or someone you love does your opinions going to 
change really fast. ﻿
top_comment.author: Brekken Quintana

comments.text:
You're seriously going to argue with me? Wow. Her lung cancer WAS caused by 
smoking. She had COPD at 35 (doctor confirmed then as well it was due to 
her smoking) she didn't stop smoking she was dead by 40. The fact that you 
have the audacity to argue this is amazing. People never want to believe it 
when something they are doing or are advocates for can be life threatening. *Shaking 
my head*
comments.author: Brekken Quintana

comments.text:
If your mother died at 40, it is highly unlikely that smoking was the 
cause. 10% to 15% of lung cancer occurs in people who have never smoked and 
are not due to radon exposure (genetic). Another 10% to 20% of lung cancer 
is caused by excessive radon exposure. This means that up to 35% of lung 
cancers are not smoking related, and those cancers (mostly aggressive small 
cell carcinomas) tend to start much earlier than those with a strong 
association with smoking. Even among smokers over 50, a fair percentage of 
their lung cancers are not entirely due to smoking but to a combination of 
genetics, radon and smoking.
comments.author: George Ford

captions.text: Wanda asks:
Hi Simon and Martina, what is it like living as non-smokers in Korea?
Ooh, Interesting personal question!
Yes~ Because we are non-smokers in Korea
And we have strong stances against smoking.
Hey, listen. I know that sometimes when we do TL;DRs
we try to be peaceful and stuff like that
A whole lot of disclaimers and what not
But I don't give a honey badger shit about smoking
because I hate smoking.
[S] Smoking sucks. [M] I have never smoked in my entire life
I've been like against it since I can't even remember
Even as a five year old I used to scold strangers on the street
I was that annoying child
I just really hate smoking[S]WAS [M]Heeeeey
[S]Hehehehey
[S]Well I said "Was" [M]I have friends that smoke
And they know that I don't like it. But I am not going to shoo them all day long
Just once. Very strongly. *demon voice*SO THEY NEVER FORGET IT
So as someone who was a big advocate of being a non-smoker
it was actually kind of a shock to move to South Korea
because Toronto was very much a non-smoking city
by the time we got older.
Right, you can't even smoke under the awnings outside of shops now
Maybe things have gotten a lot stricter since the 5 years we have been gone
Yeah, it is possible. I mean I remember going to clubs
[old voices] I remember... [S]back when I was young....
I remember going dancing in clubs like "the Phoenix"
Phoenix represent~
And people smoking inside the clubs and me not being able to breathe
But it has chanced totally since then.
So poin is Korea was a bit of a shock because smoking was EVERYWHERE!
When we first came here to Korea it was so ramped, that like
somebody asked on our TL;DR question "What is it like being a non-smoker in Korea"
and the easiest answer is: an obstacle course
Because everywhere you walked it would be people smoking,
you'd be in restaurants and people would be smoking
And you're like grilling meat in a restaurant
and the dude beside you is just blowing their cigarette smoke all over your food
I mean, it was Everywhere.
Well no. It wasn't in shopping malls.
Ok, there you go.
You couldn't smoke in a shopping mall but you could smoke in a noreabang [karaoke room]
Which is like a tiny closet. And everything smelled like cigarette smoke
and it was really gross in taxis and... BLEEEEEEGH
AHBLEEEGHH
Now we Was because as of December 2012 Korea put a ban on smoking inside restaurants and bars
And as of July 2013 they started applying a really big fine to restaurants
if they were allowing people smoke.
I think it's like $5000 for a restaurant owners and a $100 for people.
I remember reading a stat that said that the law was implaced in 2003 or something
but it wasn't really enforced that strictly.
But now we are actually starting to notice a big change in how infrequently people are smoking in restaurants.
So things are getting a lot better.
Now when it comes to the streets you still have people
blowing their dirty smoke into your face
A lot.
You don't have to add an adjective every time [M]Yeah I do
[S]Dirty and smelly smoke...
[M]Filthy hobbitses.
Listen, I'm just really against smoking because I think it's totally unfair
You have the choice of having a filter
to filter out your cigarette smoke and then you
blow your full force 2nd hand smoke into my face.
That's removing my choice.
I want to breath clean air, but you've taken it from me.
So you could be like: mmm, cigarette smoke. mmm clean air.
Just put a bag over your face as you're doing it.
[M] That's right! [S]And then tie up the bag when you're done and just throw it away.
And there you go. You don't have to effect us with your nastiness.
Yeah. It's really gross.
So who is doing all the smoking?
Now according to the statistics that we've read supposedly 40% of Korean men smoke
while only 5% of Korean women smoke,
I'm a little bit skeptical about that 2nd statistic
because we mentioned in the previous TL;DR
That we noticed that a lot of women Do smoke in secret
So if you go to bars and then go to women's washroom
Not that I've been, but Martina has been
She would notice a lot of people smoking in there in secret
to hide it from their boyfriends
They have ashtrays, they've even had lighters on a string
inside of the girls' washrooms.
So I'm not sure how many of those girls actually admitted to smoking
When that statistic was somehow made.
Supposedly the reason why so many men smoke in Korea
is because they were non-smokers before they entered the military service
and during the 2 year military service most men admitted to becoming smokers
during that time period.
Seen some things, done some things
More like:
Haven't seen my girlfriend in two years
Oh God...
Got my eyes on you Se7en
What's actually gotten so bad with smoking in Korea
that Yonsei University did a whole study about smoking effects on guys
and 73% of men were suffering from lung cancer related illnesses because of smoking.
And supposedly smoking related health issues cost Korea
10bil dollars a year.
I know, right. [S] That's A Lot.
So I think that nowadays people start to take smoking as an issue
So like in Canada, at leas, I've noticed that if you buy a cigarette pack
it has all those disgusting filthy pictures on it
It's like 70% of the picture is what your mouth looks like
And at the bottom there's the label "Marlboro"
And then they have a lot of anti-smoking commercials
and in school they try to push "don't smoke"
Teachers enforce that. But I haven't really
seen that in Korea.
Korea still has really pretty packaging on the cigarettes.
And if you go to convenience stores they are not only behind the countable, right at the cashier
they have the 3 display models.
Like Oooh look at the blue Magnum of cigarettes.
And it seems like every month I see "Oooh, it's a new mint cigarette"
Or "It's a mohito cigarette"
And at the same time supposedly buying cigarettes is really cheap in Korea
We actually spoke with people who said that they stopped smoking in America
because it's so expensive, but in Korea since it's only $2 a pack
they picked up the habit again just because it is so cheap.
Which is a really stupid fucking excuse if you ask me.
That's right. And we just cursed you out for that.
Oh, it's cheap I might as well die.
I might as well just poison myself more because it's discount poison.
I can save money of my death bid.
Why are you doing a Russian accent?
One thing I'm going to say is:
I know we always get angry trolling people that show up on our page
being like "Screw you, this is not what it's like in Korea"
But you just try to deny this. Ok?
Definitely a lot of people smoke here.
And the thing is that we live in Seoul.
And so Seoul had a different attitude than people who live in the country
Because you know people aren't going around enforcing in the country side
So people are probably still smoking inside restaurants in the country.
I'd love to hear other people's experiences that live outside of Seoul.
What's it like? Is there a non-smoking ban or is it just something happening in the Seoul area?
Well there is also difference in different parts of Seoul.
I was speaking with somebody outside about smoking in Korea
and they said that the girls' smoking in secret he doesn't notice it that much in Hongdae
as much as he does in other parts of Seoul.
Because Hongdae is more of a liberal area.
I remember my co-teachers when I was teaching.
You didn't really smoke in front of your elders
you didn't really smoke in front of your principle.
But you might secretly smoke elsewhere.
So I guess it depends on the situation of etiquette in Korea.
Moral of the story is that you smoke cigarettes you're going to get pregnant and then you die.
Wait... I have not dated people over smoking.
I have seriously been like: this could be my dream guy
and he's like "I smoke"
And I'm like "Our relationship is over"
I'm with a non-smoker.
The best.
I'm glad that when I kiss you, you don't taste like an ashtray.
Like a pickled anus.
That's right.
Anyhow, if you want to know more about our thoughts about Kpop idols smoking
Trust me, we've seen it in person.
Make sure you click on the blog link right here.
And we'll write more about that.
Seriously why would you smoke when you're a singer.
Hey, hey,HEY! Save that for the blog. Save that for the blog.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR

Or check out the questions already asked and you can thumb them up to bring them to our attention.

where we talk about why smoking sucks.
And we don't hide our resentment towards smokers
We..um... shan't be talking about this topic again.
No? [M]No.
It's not that I won't be friends with someone who smokes
I just won't invite him to my home.
Or let them smoke in my car.
Or near me or my pets
We don't have a car.
You know what I'm saying.
On our scooter.

STOP SMOKING!
